Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: Hands-on Modules for Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer, A Market Transition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovation Corps for Learning Program (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to increase the scale and impact of desk-top fluid mechanics and heat transfer experiments at a price comparable to that of a textbook. Engineering education requires realistic hands-on learning experiences, available throughout the curriculum. However, the equipment currently available for classroom use is limited primarily to robotics and electronics, though many other branches of engineering would benefit immensely from similar innovations. Currently, in the fields of chemical, mechanical and civil engineering the large size and high cost of equipment allows for hands-on experiences only in a laboratory setting scheduled for the final two to three semesters of college. This project will address this problem by making available miniaturized thermal fluids systems with a cost of approximately one to two hundred dollars per set. Having such systems available enables realistic, hands-on learning throughout an engineering curriculum in the standard classroom. Besides improvements to instruction, exposure at an earlier stage in the curriculum will enhance recruitment and retention within engineering majors.

The currently available equipment developed by the project team includes venturi meters, shell and tube heat exchangers, double pipe heat exchangers, and a hydraulic loss apparatus all approximately the same size as a hardbound textbook. These represent equipment and processes of interest in mechanical, chemical and civil engineering. In the classroom, this equipment allows students to link theoretical concepts and correlations to physical reality in a compact device they can manipulate,observe, take data and even take home for homework exercises. Learning is enhanced by the equipment being miniaturizations of common larger scale industrial or pilot scale laboratory equipment. The instructor will not have to use examples from other not-so-relevant hands-on examples, such as cooling of a coffee cup. Students can conduct experiments and analyze data from miniature representations of actual equipment utilized in industry. This I-Corps for Learning project will help to promote broad usage of such equipment, not only in conventional programs, but also those with limited resources, and in distance education and massive on-line classroom applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this I-CORP L project the investigators evaluated the commercial landscape around a set of small and very low-cost fluid mechanics and heat transfer equipment aimed at enabling hands-on learning for the engineering classroom and take-home non-laboratory settings. Hands on and active learning are already known to increase student conceptual understanding. In addition to providing engineering instructors with additional tools to provide hands-on and active learning opportunities, this technology has the potential of impacting engineering education in remote, space-limited, and funding-limited environments which may be unable to support traditional engineering laboratories. A set of Low Cost-Miniaturized Equipment typically shown to prospective customers and Key Partners are provided in the attached images. While not the first aspect of an interaction, showing these to customers had a way of exciting them about the technology where we begin to hear many “I need it now’s.”

There are two possible paths to commercialization for this technology. First we can license it to an existing company. Alternately, we could follow the example of companies such as Arduino, and offer the technology through an open source model. In this later case, equipment plans would be freely available. However, the equipment will also be available for purchase. As the equipment manufacture requires both time and skill, there is likely still to be a market for the pre-fabricated equipment. A final component of this business model is that the company created for this would also function as a rapid design and prototyping firm and help engineering educators create philosophically similar equipment at the price of a minimum initial order. This new equipment would become a new product for the company, with plans available in an open source manner.

At present the low cost equipment has been offered to a manufacturer for consideration. In addition, grant proposals continue to be envisioned and submitted with the goal of equipping a university facility to initiate establishment of a client-service model that, when funding is made available, is expected to lead to a self-sustaining facility. 

Intellectual Merit centers on knowledge about customer needs, commercial segments, value propositions, channels and revenue streams through the Business Model Canvas approach. Training has occurred for the PI, Entrepreneurial Lead, and Mentor in the Lean Launch Business Model. Many insights were gained from the interview process from ideas for equipment manufacture, to classroom and programmatic implementation.

Broader Impact is evident in the wide variety of faculty from varied disciplines who are showing interest in the low cost easily manufactured engineering process and mechanical equipment. The low cost nature, open source model will allow faculty and students to be involved in the development and learning to manufacture processes. Because of definitive interest expressed by equipment supply companies this technology may become available soon for implantation worldwide, for small to large classes, use in remote low resources environments all the way to well-endowed university programs.
